ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Bristol - Page
ai_page.body:
Get permission to make improvements to your council home

If you’re a council tenant, you must get our written permission before you make any alterations or improvements to your home.

What counts as an improvement or alteration

You need our written permission for things like:

  • installing a new kitchen or bathroom
  • putting in central heating or a new boiler
  • changing internal doors
  • fitting laminate or wood floors
  • installing a shower if you don’t already have one
  • installing a satellite dish
  • putting up a shed, greenhouse or garage in your garden
  • installing a drive or dropped kerb
  • replacing doors or windows
  • putting up a fence or wall

If you’re not sure if your planned work counts as an improvement, contact your local housing officer.

Work you must not do

You must not:

  • take out any structural walls, including chimney breasts
  • remove or alter any load bearing walls or structures
  • remove or alter any gas, electric or water installations unless a qualified tradesperson does the work

If you do any work that’s not allowed or not safe, you may have to return the property to its original state or pay to put things right.

How to get permission

To ask for written permission, you need to:

  1. Contact your local housing officer to discuss your plans
  2. Send us written details of your proposed improvement or alteration, including:
    • what work you want to do
    • who will be carrying out the work
    • the qualifications of the person or company doing the work
    • details of any appliances or materials to be used
    • drawings or diagrams if relevant

You can upload documents when you use our online form.

Request permission to make alterations to your council home

After you apply

We’ll look at your request and let you know in writing if you have our permission.  We may give you conditions you must follow or request more information.

If you do work without our permission, we may ask you to return the property to its original condition, and you may be charged for any damage.

If you need help

For advice or if you need help, contact your local housing officer.

ai_business_case.letter:
To the CEO,

As the usability lead assessing the current service experience for council tenants seeking permission for property alterations, I have analyzed the provided customer persona, feedback, and the existing webpage content. Based on this review, I recommend targeted improvements that can enhance customer satisfaction, increase process efficiency, and reduce administrative costs.

Customer Insights:
David, a typical council tenant, is comfortable using online services and prefers clear, straightforward steps with minimal hassle. His main concern is the lack of clarity regarding processing times and application status updates, which can lead to anxiety and potential delays.

Current Feedback and Content Evaluation:
The positive aspect is that the webpage successfully explains the process of requesting permission and outlines what constitutes acceptable improvements. However, the feedback indicates that adding explicit information about approval timelines and application status checks would significantly improve clarity.

Recommendations for Improvements:

1. Incorporate Estimated Timelines:
   - Embed clear, upfront information about typical processing times for permission requests.
   - Implement an automated notification system to update tenants at key stages of their application.
Impact: This reduces tenant uncertainty, decreases follow-up inquiries, and frees staffing resources, ultimately saving money.

2. Add a Step-by-Step Checklist:
   - Include a visual summary or checklist summarizing the necessary steps, required documents, and who to contact.
   - Use plain language and icons for quick comprehension.
Impact: Simplifies the process, reduces errors or omissions in applications, and accelerates decision-making.

3. Enable Application Status Tracking:
   - Develop a portal feature allowing tenants to check real-time status updates online.
   - Send automatic email or SMS alerts upon receipt, review, and decision.
Impact: Enhances transparency, improves customer trust, and minimizes unnecessary manual communication from the housing team.

4. Streamline the Form Submission:
   - Ensure the online form is user-friendly, with guidance prompts and validation to prevent incomplete submissions.
Impact: Reduces administrative follow-up and speeds up approval processes.

Conclusion:
Implementing these improvements will significantly enhance service usability for tenants like David. Clearer communication of timelines and real-time updates will boost tenant confidence and satisfaction, while automation and simplified processes will reduce administrative burdens and costs for the council.

I recommend prioritizing these usability enhancements as part of our digital transformation efforts to improve service efficiency, reduce administrative workload, and deliver a better experience for our residents.

Respectfully,

[Web Manager Name]
Usability & Service Improvement Specialist
